newsitem.title: BULGARIA: AMOCO CHANGES TACK WITH EAST EUROPE RETAIL SALE.
newsitem.headline: AMOCO CHANGES TACK WITH EAST EUROPE RETAIL SALE.

text.p: Amoco Corp , which on Wednesday announced the sale of its retail petrol stations in Eastern Europe, needed to adapt to remain competitive in the world petrol market, company officials said.

"Amoco's decision is based on world-wide competitive challenges affecting the entire petroleum industry beyond Poland, Romania and Bulgaria," said James Shields, managing director of Amoco Bulgaria Petroleum Products Ltd.
Shields said many of the world's biggest oil companies were planning to merge refining and marketing operations.

"This is a significant event for the petroleum industry ...any responsible company would refocus on its worldwide competitive challenges and...do what it must do or that company will not exist," Shields said.
Amoco said it would sell its petrol stations in Poland, Romania and Bulgaria but the move would not affect its other businesses such as exploration and production and chemical activities.
Amoco's Director of Public and Government Affairs Gary Stewart said Amoco could be competitive in retail stations in the Americas and "therefore that is where we must be".
"When you look at the world situation we are not as competitive in Europe," Stewart said.

Last month Amoco opened its first petrol station in the Black Sea port of Bourgas and two other stations in Sofia and Plovdiv are under construction. Shields said the Bourgas station had been highly successful.
Amoco was the second foreign petrol retailer in Bulgaria after the Royal Dutch/Shell Group , which has built 19 filling stations since 1993 and has invested $35 million. REUTER
